intro: Patagonium hispidulum, commonly known as the hairy Patagonian grass, is a flowering plant native to the southern regions of South America. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and hairy leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as steppes and rocky soils, adapting to the harsh climate of Patagonia. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are clustered in spikelets, a common feature among grasses. Patagonium hispidulum plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing forage for local wildlife.
